results.title: Seal Island
results.creator_credit: James Algar and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “True Life Adventures”.
A study of the fur-bearing Alaskan seals during the mating season when the seals return to the barren place of their own birth to breed.

results.title: Inspired design and costume sketches
results.brief_description: Costume designers don’t always rely on sketches of their creations. True History of the Kelly Gang designer Alice Babidge sketches to distil references, while Judy & Punch designer Edie Kurzer gets more inspiration from objects.

constellations_primary.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_primary.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

results.description:
Judy & Punch (2019) costume designer Edie Kurzer often explores mood and atmosphere with images instead of using them as direct influences. While she may use sketches to work through details, she gains more inspiration from objects like feathers, buttons or fabrics, and then works with a fabric cutter, in this case Justine Coultham, who sketches how the costume should be cut and assembled.   

Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang (2019) costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”, while the torn faces on the photos help the actors imagine how they’ll inhabit the character.
description_for_label:

While she may use sketches to work through details, she gains more inspiration from objects like feathers, buttons or fabrics, and then works with a fabric cutter, in this case Justine Coultham, who sketches how the costume should be cut and assembled.   

Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang (2019) costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”, while the torn faces on the photos help the actors imagine how they’ll inhabit the character.

results.title: Decisions in academic departments
results.creator_credit: George Pashuk and University of New South Wales. Tertiary Education Research Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Trigger series 7. Managing people”.
Six dramatisations dealing with interpersonal aspects of staff management are designed to trigger discussion. Although set in a university the issues raised are common to all organisations.

results.title: Theft of the Mona Lisa
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner, Suzanne Duroux and Stoner Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Treasures of the world”.
The world’s most famous painting, Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa disappeared from The Louvre in 1911. It would be another two years before she was safely recovered. This program traces the suspects and conspiracy theories, as well as the environment in which the world’s most famous Renaissance man painted. It covers public reaction to the theft, techniques and innovations used in the painting, motivation behind the theft and the repercussions to the art world and society as a whole once she was found. Narrated by Krisha Fairchild.

results.title: Guernica: testimony of war
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Duroux, Barry Stoner and Stoner Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Treasures of the world”.
A detailed documentary investigating the genesis and impact of Pablo Picasso’s influential work, Guernica. Picasso was approached to provide a centrepiece for the Spanish pavilion at the Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques des la vie Moderne 1937 in Paris. For months he searched for inspiration, plagued by turmoil in his personal life, and the political problems savaging Spain at the time. Then, on April 26th 1937, the Spanish village of Guernica was mercilessly reduced to rubble by tonnes of explosive which killed many. This display of military power, ordered by Franco to break resistance against nationalist forces, left seventy percent of the town destroyed, and attracted a large protest in Paris. Stunned by the stark monochromatic photographs of this destruction, Picasso began to map out the images for what would become his own interpretation of and reaction to this apocalyptic vision of war. The first drafts of the composition, the motifs which begin to take shape, and the final result of this bold political statement on the artists’s behalf are explored in great detail, utilising archival materials and interviews with art historians.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Suzanne Duroux, Barry Stoner and Stoner Productions
